introduction.p:
From the matrix representation of {\bf I} in Eq. , it is obvious that it is a symmetric matrix. We say that moment of inertia is a symmetric tensor. Since symmetric matrices can always be diagonalized, there is a choice of direction of the body-attached axes so that off-diagonal elements turn out to be zero. We call these axes principal axes. In principal axes we will have only three non-zero moment of inertia components; in that case, we just denote them by simpler symbols, I_1, I_2, I_3.
{\bf I} = \begin{pmatrix} I_1 \amp 0 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp I_2 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp I_3 \end{pmatrix}
Denoting x,y,z by x_1,\,x_2,\,x_3 for simplicity and subscripts by simply 1,\,2,\,3 instead of x,y,z, we have
I_1 = \sum m (x_2^2 + x_3^2),\ \ I_2 = \sum m (x_1^2 + x_3^2),\ \ I_3 = \sum m (x_1^2 + x_2^2).
From these, it is easy to see that sum of two of these moments of inertia cannot exceed the third.
I_1 + I_2 = \sum m (x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 2x_3^2) \ge \sum m (x_1^2 + x_2^2) = I_3.

Based on the values of I_1,\ I_2,\ I_3 we can classify systems into three categories: (1) if I_1=I_2=I_3, then we have spherical top, (2) if I_1 = I_2 \ne I_3, then we have symmetrical top, and (3) if all I_i are diferent, then we have asymmetrical top. Often, we work with systems that are elongated along one dimension, such as rod or linear molecules. In that case, we will have I_1=I_2 and I_3=0. This type of system is called a rotator.
If there are symmetries in a rigid body, it is much simpler to guess the directions of principal axes. For instance, in the case of sphere, every axis through the CM is a principal axis.

sidebyside.p: In the case of a cylinder, one prinicipal axis will be the axis of the cylinder and the other two will be axes perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder and passing through the CM. In this case, we will get I_1=I_2 and I_3.

introduction.p:
A calculation on a cylinder of mass M, height H and radius R will show that moment of inertia tensor with respect to principal axes will be
{\bf I} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{4}MR^2 + \frac{1}{12}MH^2 \amp 0 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp \frac{1}{4}MR^2 + \frac{1}{12}MH^2 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \frac{1}{2}MR^2 \end{pmatrix}

sidebyside.p: When masses are restricted to be in a plane, we call it a coplanar system. For a coplanar system, say in the xy plane, let I_{1} and I_2 be moments of inertia about principal axes in xy-plane and I_3 be about principal axis perpendicular to the plane.

introduction.p:
Since z=0 for all particles in this system, we have
I_1 = \sum m y^2,\ \ I_2 = \sum m x^2,\ \ I_3 = \sum m (x^2 + y^2).
Clearly, for coplanar systems we must have
I_3 = I_1 + I_2.

example.title: Moment of Inertia of a Dumbbell

sidebyside.p: We want to find moment of inertia of a dumbbell with respect to two different coordinate systems shown in . Find all nine moments of inertia in Oxyz and Ox'y'z'.

solution.p:
We need coordinates of the two masses in the two systems. From , we read off the following for the mass (say 1) on the right.
x_1 = l\cos\theta,\ \ y_1 = l \sin\theta,\ \ z_1 = 0 x'_1 = l,\ \ y'_1 = 0,\ \ z'_1 = 0
The coordinates of the other particle are negative of these values. Therefore, we get the following moments of inertia in Oxyz.
\amp I_{xx} = 2m l^2 \sin^2\theta,\ \ I_{yy} = 2m l^2 \cos^2\theta,\ \ I_{zz} = 2m l^2, \amp I_{xy} = -2m l^2 \sin\theta\,\cos\theta,\ \ I_{xz} = 0,\ \ I_{yz} = 0.
Organizing this in matrix we have the following in Oxyz.
{\bf I} = \begin{pmatrix} 2m l^2 \sin^2\theta \amp -2m l^2 \sin\theta\,\cos\theta \amp 0\\ -2m l^2 \sin\theta\,\cos\theta \amp 2m l^2 \cos^2\theta \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2m l^2 \end{pmatrix}
In Ox'y'z', we will get
\amp I_{x'x'} = 0,\ \ I_{y'y'} = 2m l^2,\ \ I_{z'z'} = 2m l^2, \amp I_{x'y'} = 0,\ \ I_{x'z'} = 0,\ \ I_{y'z'} = 0.
Organizing this in matrix we have the following in Ox'y'z'.
{\bf I'} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 2m l^2 \amp 0\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2m l^2 \end{pmatrix}

example.title: Principal Moments of Inertia of a Cone

statement.p: Find principal moments of inertia of a circular-based cone with radius R and height h.

sidebyside.p: To find the principal moments of inertia about the CM at O, we first find moment of inertia about the apex at O' using axes parallel to the principal axes, and then make use of parallel axis theorem as illustrated in . We also make use of cylindrical coordinates since integrals will work out more easily there.

solution.p:
An element of mass dm = \rho\,dV at coordinates (x',y',z') here will be
dm = \rho r'dr' d\phi' dz',
where upper limit of integration on radial distance r' = \sqrt{ {x'}^2 + {y'}^2 } depends on z' from the ratio of sides of similar triangles,
\frac{r'_\text{max}}{z'} = \frac{R}{h},\ \ \longrightarrow\ \ r'_\text{max} = \frac{R}{h}\, z'.
Mass of the cone will be
M \amp = 2\pi \rho \int_0^h dz'\, \int_0^{r'_\text{max}}\, r'dr' \amp = \frac{2\pi \rho R^2}{2 h^2} \int_0^h\, z'\, dz' = \frac{\pi R^2 h}{3}\, \rho.
To find I_{z'z'} we need
I_{z'z'} \amp = \int \rho \left(x^2 + y^2 \right) dV \amp = \rho \int {r'}^2 r'dr' d\phi' dz' \amp = \frac{ 2\pi R^4 \rho}{4h^4} \int_0^h {z'}^4 dz' \amp = \frac{ \pi R^4 h \rho}{10} = \frac{3}{10}\,MR^2.

For I_{x'x'}=I_{y'y'}, we need only one calculation.
I_{x'x'} \amp = \int \rho \left(y^2 + z^2 \right) dV \amp = \rho \int dz'\int r' dr'\, \int d\phi' \left( {r'}^2 \sin^2\phi' + {z'}^2\right) \amp = \rho \int dz'\int r' dr'\, \left( \pi {r'}^2 + 2\pi {z'}^2\right) \amp = \rho \int dz' \left( \frac{\pi}{4}{Rz'/h}^4 + \pi {Rz'/h}^2 {z'}^2\right)
\amp = \rho \left( \frac{\pi}{20}(R/h)^4 h^5 + \frac{1}{5}\,\pi (R/h)^2 h^5\right) \amp = \frac{\pi\rho R^2 h}{3} \left( \frac{3}{20} R^2 + \frac{3}{5}h^2 \right) \amp = \frac{3}{5}\,M \left( \frac{1}{4} R^2 + h^2 \right)

To make use of parallel axis theorem to get I_{xx}, I_{yy}, I_{zz} through the CM, we need to locate the CM of the cone. We just need to find the z'_\text{cm}. This will be at
z'_\text{cm} = \frac{1}{M}\int z' dV = \frac{3}{4}\, h.
Now, we use parallel axis theorem to get
I_{xx} \amp = I_{x'x'} - M {z'}_\text{cm}^2 = \frac{3}{5}\,M \left( \frac{1}{4} R^2 + h^2 \right) - \frac{9}{16} h^2 \amp = \frac{3}{20}\,MR^2 + \frac{3}{80}\,Mh^2. I_{yy} \amp = I_{xx} = \frac{3}{20}\,MR^2 + \frac{3}{80}\,Mh^2. I_{zz} \amp = \frac{3}{10}\,MR^2.

subsection.title: Parallel Axis Theorem
subsection.p: Often we want moment of inertia about an axis that does not pass through center of mass. We have seen this before, for instance, in the case of moment of inertia of a rod about an axis through the edge.

sidebyside.p:
Given moment of inertia I_{1}=\frac{1}{12}ML^2 about axis 1 through the center of the rod, the moment of inertia about an axis 1' through the edge and parallel to the axis through the CM was
I_{1'} = I_{1} + Ma^2 = \frac{1}{3}ML^2.

subsection.p: We want to generalize it. Suppose we have I_1,\, I_2,\ I_3 are moments of inertial about principal axes 1,\, 2,\ 3 respectively, origin O at CM. Let there be axes 1',\, 2',\ 3' that are parallel to 1,\, 2,\ 3 but with origin at A in the body such that the displacment from O to A be \vec a.

Consider a point P in the body. Let \vec r be its position with respect to O and \vec r' with respect to A. Then
\vec r = \vec r' + \vec a.
The diagonal components of the moment of inertia will become
I_{x'x'} \amp = \sum m (y'^2 + z'^2) \amp \sum m [(y-a_y)^2 + (z-a_z)^2] \amp \sum m (y^2 + z^2) + \sum m (a_y^2 + a_z^2) -2a_y\sum m y - 2a_z\sum m z
Last two terms here will be zero since O is at the CM, i.e, since \sum m \vec r = 0, we will end up with
I_{x'x'} = \sum m (y^2 + z^2) + \sum m (a_y^2 + a_z^2) = I_{xx} + \sum m (a_y^2 + a_z^2).
Similarly for I_{y'y'} and I_{z'z'}. For off-diagonal components, lets look at I_{x'y'}.
I_{x'y'} \amp = - \sum m x'y' \amp = - \sum m (x-a_x)(y-a_y) \amp = - \sum m x y - \sum m a_xa_y + a_x\sum m y + a_y \sum m x \amp = I_{xy} - \sum m a_xa_y + 0 + 0 = I_{xy} - \sum m a_xa_y
Similarly, for other off-diagonal components. Thus, although moment of inertia {\bf I} was diagonal with origin of principal axes at CM, it is not diagonal if origin is not at CM.

example.title: Radius of Gyration of a Sphere About an Axis Tangent to the Edge

statement.p: What is the radius of gyration of a solid sphere of mass M and radius R about an axis that is tangent to its surface? Assume the sphere to be of unform density.

solution.p: Recall the definition of radius of gyration. It's the distance from the axis, usually denoted by R_G, such that moment of inertia about the axis is I = M R_G^2.

We will start with the previously known fact that moment of inertia of a sphere about an axis passing through the center is
I_0 = \frac{2}{5}MR^2.
Now, we want moment of inertia about an axis A that is parallel to the axis through the CM but is at a distance R away. Hence, moment of inertia about A will be
I_A = I_0 + MR^2 = \frac{7}{5} MR^2.
Now, to get radius of gyration, we equate this to MR_G^2. This gives us
R_G = \sqrt{\frac{7}{5}}\, R.

exercise.title: Principal Moment of Inertia of Water Molecule

sidebyside.p: Use symmetry arguments to guess principal axes and find moments of inertia about them for a water molecule with m_1=m_3=m and m_2=M and l being the bond length and \theta angle between the bonds. Use a=l\sin\theta/2 and h=l\cos\theta/2.

answer.p: I_{xx}\frac{2mM h^2}{M + 2m}, I_{yy}=2 m a^2, I_{zz} = I_{xx} + I_{yy}.

sidebyside.p:
In two principal axes are shown; z-axis is coming out of the page. I have used symmetry to place CM at the center of the horizontal divider. By placing 2m at Q and M at P, we get
\bar{OP} = \frac{2m\,l\cos(\theta/2) }{M+2m} = \frac{2mh}{M+2m}.

solution.p:
Distance OQ will be
\bar{OQ} = h - \bar{OP} = \frac{M\,h }{M+2m}.
The horizontal distance of masses m are a = l\sin(\theta/2). Now, we write Cartesian coordinates of the three masses, with m_1 being the lower left corner.
\amp x_1 = - a,\ \ y_1 = - \frac{M\,h }{M+2m},\ \ z_1 = 0. \amp x_2 = 0,\ \ y_2 = \frac{2m\,h }{M+2m},\ \ z_2 = 0. \amp x_3 = + a = -x_1,\ \ y_3 = - \frac{M\,h}{M+2m}=y_1,\ \ z_3 = 0.
The diagonal components of moment of inertia will be
I_{xx} \amp = m_1 (y_1^2 + z_1^2) + m_2 (y_2^2 + z_2^2) + m_3 (y_3^2 + z_3^2) \amp = 2m \left(\frac{M\,h }{M+2m}\right)^2 + M \left( \frac{2m\,h }{M+2m}\right)^2 \amp = \frac{2mM h^2}{M + 2m}.
I_{yy} \amp = m_1 (x_1^2 + z_1^2) + m_2 (x_2^2 + z_2^2) + m_3 (x_3^2 + z_3^2) \amp = 2m a^2 + M \times 0 = 2 m a^2.
Since this is a coplanar system, we must have
I_{zz} = I_{xx} + I _{yy} = 2m a^2 + \frac{2mM\,h^2 }{M+2m}.
We can verify it by carrying out calculation explicitly.
I_{zz} \amp = m_1 (x_1^2 + y_1^2) + m_2 (x_2^2 + y_2^2) + m_3 (x_3^2 + y_3^2) \amp = 2m a^2 + 2m \left( \frac{M\,h }{M+2m} \right)^2 + M \left( \frac{2m\,h }{M+2m} \right)^2 \amp = 2m a^2 + \frac{2mM\,h^2 }{M+2m}.
Let's work out one of th eoff-diagonal components. Let's say we want I_{xy}.
I_{xy} \amp = - m_1 x_1 y_1 - m_2 x_2 y_2 - m_3 x_3 y_3 \amp = - m x_1 y_1 - 0 - m (-x_1) (y_1) = 0.
